FRAGMENTS
In this compelling narrative, a complex web of interconnected lives unfolds, delving into themes of mystery, secrets, and the enduring power of memory. Through the intertwining paths of various individuals, hidden truths and personal struggles come to light. While a missing girl and a suspicious neighbor suspected of being the perpetrator disrupt the protagonist's world, he must confronts his own fears, conflicts, and past traumas. The story explores profound human connections, the resilience of the human spirit, and the profound influence of the past on the present. Prepare yourself for an engrossing journey through intertwined lives and narratives, where appearances are deceiving and the pursuit of truth carries a significant price.
c:
Well, that was boring...

Fragments is a collection of 25 short stories that are interconnected. Each story can be read on its own (but might not make any sense), but some things are better understood if you read the other stories too. Some stories are not in chronological order. To read the story, go to the stories tagged #fragments_by_sd, sort by oldest, and start from the beginning. Other stories with the same tag might get added later, so make sure you read the right one (mine). Enjoy!

The following is a behind-the-scenes look at the story, where I talk about the writing process and the ideas behind it. There may be spoilers, so it's better to read the story first.

I started writing stories again on this platform after a while. Luckily, I joined when #YoStoWriMo was still ongoing, but most of it was already over. However, I decided to start writing from the first prompt, using the titles as inspiration. Initially, I only planned to write individual stories.

When I saw the prompt for day 7 and the following days, I got the idea to write something bigger. The plan was to make each story as standalone as possible, but as I continued writing, it became harder to keep them independent yet connected. I did my best to make everything coherent, and I hope I succeeded.

When I began writing this, I had a general idea of the overall story, but the individual stories were written as I went along. I even changed my ideas for the stories as I wrote them. I aimed to make everything make sense without any inconsistencies. My main challenge was to have each individual story somehow relate to the given title while being part of the whole. This sometimes required using transitional segments, and some stories may have felt slightly rushed.

You may notice that the initial stories were written in a more professional style, showcasing an expanded vocabulary. However, as the narrative progressed, I decided to adopt a more casual style. The idea was that as the main character delves into his past, particularly his childhood, the writing style would change to reflect that, becoming more childlike.

By the way, did you notice? The story is mostly written in first-person narrative, as if I am the main character. I use the pseudonym Sherlock Doyle for my online presence. The neighbor, an alter ego of (mine and) the main character, is Dr. Shelly Cooke. Their names are anagrams, symbolizing their shared identity all along.

Some parts of the story mirror my own life, but they are very minor. And no, I don't have any criminal activities in my past. I don't have a neighbor who is a serial killer or an alter ego. Even if I did, I wouldn't know! That last sentence is a joke. My stories do not reflect who I am, but I do draw inspiration from my life and the people around me.
